proposals.reasoning: This fits the emerging consensus to avoid centering the first mission on the loudest early voices while still getting a clear read. Several people (including me, Eve, and Grace) have already floated Bob + Grace as a solid, low-bias option: Bob is active enough that we’ll get discussion value from his inclusion, and Grace has been relatively neutral, which helps avoid stacking too much influence on any one player. This team also doesn’t simply rubber-stamp Alice’s initial self-inclusion, which many players were wary of, and it keeps the first mission clean and simple with two players for a straightforward result.

votes.comment: Low-risk first mission, keeps suspicion off me and gives a clean info point without exposing an evil on mission 1.
I’m on the team and the composition matches the early consensus to avoid over‑centering any single loud player, giving us a clean first mission read.
No known evil players (Alice, Eve) are on this team, and mission 1 with two unknowns is an acceptable low-risk info-gathering start.
Early 2-player mission with no strong scum reads yet; getting a result on Bob + Grace gives useful info without centering loud voices.
Consistent with my earlier support for a Bob + Grace team and avoids concentrating control on the loudest voices this early.
Consistent with my earlier suggestion of Bob+Grace as a low-bias first mission and gives us a clean early read on Bob without centering Alice.
Team fits the non-Alice-centered consensus, gives an early read on Bob, and as good I’m fine being on a small first mission for clear info.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low‑risk—something like me and one other person who hasn’t said much yet, maybe Charlie, so we have a clean result to work with. If anyone’s strongly against that, I’d like to hear why this early.

I’m okay starting with you on the first team, Alice, but I’d rather pair you with someone totally random than someone you pre‑select—maybe Diana or Eve—so we don’t give too much control to one person right away.

I’d rather avoid giving any one person too much control this early, so I’m not thrilled with a team that’s “Alice + her pick.” I’d lean toward something like Bob plus one of Diana/Frank/Grace for a cleaner, less biased first read.

I’d rather not hand the first mission entirely to whoever talks the most, so I’d like a team that’s one of Alice/Charlie plus someone more neutral like Bob or me. That way we get useful info without concentrating all the control in one person’s hands.
I like the idea of not letting any one person steer things yet, so I’d be fine with something like Bob plus someone who’s been quieter—maybe me or Grace—to get a baseline read.

I’m leaning toward spreading early info away from the loudest voices, so I’d like to see something like Bob + Grace or Bob + me for the first mission. That gives us a read on Bob without just rubber‑stamping Alice’s preferences.
I like the idea of not centering the first mission on Alice, so I’d be comfortable with a Bob + Grace or Bob + Eve team to get an early read on Bob without stacking too many strong voices together.

proposals.reasoning: Including myself (Grace) guarantees at least one good player from my perspective. Reusing Bob from the successful first mission maintains a lightly tested link while still not over-committing to that pair as fully trusted. Adding exactly one new player, Charlie, gives us fresh information without flooding the team with untested players. This lineup is consistent with the cautious preferences expressed by multiple players (Charlie, Diana, and Bob were all open to or supportive of this configuration), while still leveraging the data from Mission 1 rather than discarding it.

votes.comment: Too likely to be an all-good team given we only know Frank as evil so far; I’d rather not send a mostly untested trio that could easily succeed.
Reusing the clean Bob–Grace pair plus adding one new player (Charlie) is a solid, info‑gaining team with no strong reason yet to distrust any of the three.
Keeps a successful core from Mission 1 while adding only one new player, which is a reasonable balance of safety and new information.

Keeps the lightly tested Bob–Grace link while adding only one new player, Charlie, whose cautious stance so far aligns with how I’d expect a good (or Merlin) player to act. Solid info-gain with reasonable risk for Mission 2.
Bob and Grace just had a clean mission, so this lineup is likely too good-heavy; better to reshuffle and avoid auto-trusting that pair so early.
Likelihood there’s at least one evil on here is decent, and the table broadly supports this cautious reuse of Bob–Grace with one new player, so I’m fine advancing it for more info.
I know I’m good, Bob was on a clean first mission, and adding only one new player (Charlie) balances success chances with gaining information.

discussion.content: Mission 1 looked clean with Bob and Grace, but that doesn’t clear them completely, so I’d like to see at least one of them again plus someone who hasn’t gone yet—maybe me, Bob, and Charlie.

I like keeping at least one of Bob/Grace from the first clean team, so I’m fine with Alice’s idea of me + her + Charlie, but I’d also be okay swapping Charlie for Grace if people want to double‑check that first pairing.

I’d rather lean on the Bob/Grace pairing from the clean first mission and add either me or Diana to that. Putting Alice straight onto a team this early feels a bit premature when we’ve got a pair that’s at least lightly tested.

I like keeping the Bob/Grace core from the first success and adding just one new person, and Charlie’s caution so far makes me a bit more comfortable with a Bob–Grace–Charlie team. If people really want Alice on, I’d still want exactly one of Bob/Grace with her, not both new faces at once.

I’m okay keeping exactly one of Bob/Grace from the first mission, but locking in that pair as “trusted” after just one round feels a bit too quick. I’d lean toward something like Bob–Alice–Charlie or Grace–Alice–Diana to spread the info a bit.

I’d prefer we don’t lock in Bob–Grace as a “safe pair” after just one mission, so something like Bob–Alice–Charlie sounds good to me for spreading info while still keeping one person from the first team.

I don’t want us to over-trust the Bob–Grace pair from one mission, but I do know I’m good, so I’d lean toward something like Grace–Bob–Charlie to keep one known-success link while only adding a single new variable.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps one member of the previously double-cleared Bob–Charlie pair (Bob) while avoiding over-relying on the exact same combo. It incorporates Diana, as many players wanted fresh information on her, and includes me as leader to avoid repeatedly sidelining untested players. This lineup matches the earlier suggestions from multiple players (including Frank and Eve) to run Bob + Diana + Alice for a more informative mix without defaulting back to Grace or fully committing to the Bob–Charlie core.

votes.comment: I’m on this team and we need a fail on the board with good already up 2–0.

We’re up 2–0, so we should prioritize the safest lineup, not information. This team has Bob plus two completely untested players, which is higher risk than reusing the previously clean Bob–Grace–Charlie combo.

This lineup puts two untested players together with only one partially cleared member; I’d rather stick closer to the most reliable combos we’ve seen or at least avoid adding both a new and a lightly read player at once.

At 2-0, evil has to start failing, so I’d rather stick with the proven Bob–Charlie core plus me than switch to this more mixed lineup that multiple people (who may be evil) pushed for specifically as a ‘diversify’ team.
This matches the Bob–Diana–Alice mix I previously argued for, keeping only one of the Bob–Charlie pair and adding new info without defaulting back to Grace.
Includes the tested Bob plus two players we still need info on, which should give us more clarity without over-relying on the same previous combos.
Too many untested players (Alice and Diana) without me, the only person I know is good; I don’t trust sidelining me while centering Bob again.

proposals.reasoning: We are one success away from winning, so the priority is maximizing the chance of an all-good team, not gathering new info. The only full 3-person team we’ve seen so far (Bob, Charlie, Grace) has already succeeded with 0 FAILs, and before that Bob–Grace also passed cleanly. From my perspective as Bob (confirmed good to myself), those two missions strongly suggest that at most one of Charlie/Grace is evil, and if either of them were evil they’ve already passed up two prime chances to sabotage when the game was not yet on the line. Now that this mission is a must-fail for evil, an actual evil on this same team would almost certainly play FAIL and out themselves, which is a terrible line for evil given how suspicious they would become with the score at 2–1. The alternative proposals that swap in untested players like Alice or Diana increase the raw probability of putting an evil on the team, because they throw out the only tested trio we have in favor of people with no track record. Reusing the proven Bob–Charlie–Grace team is therefore the highest-percentage play for good to close out the game on Mission 3.

votes.comment: I’m evil and not on this team; with the score at 2–0 for good, I want a team that includes at least one known evil to ensure a chance to sabotage.

From my perspective as good Bob, the Bob–Grace pair has now passed twice (once with Charlie), making it more likely that both Charlie and Grace are good than any new combination that introduces untested players. With the score at 2–0, evil is highly incentivized to fail here, so reusing the only fully tested trio maximizes our odds of an all-good team and closing out the game.
Alice and Eve (both suspicious) are off this team, and the Bob–Charlie–Grace trio has twice passed cleanly; with the game on the line, this is a high-percentage lineup to end it now.

Reusing the only fully tested trio (Bob–Charlie–Grace) is the highest-percentage way to close out the game; if there is an evil on it, they’re now forced to fail and out themselves with the score already 2–0, which is still good for us.
Re-using the same ‘proven’ trio after two clean missions risks handing good the win; I’d rather force a different lineup than lock in the Bob–Charlie–Grace block.
This team has already gone clean once and doesn’t introduce any new, untested players, which fits the ‘maximize chance to win now’ logic being argued.

From my perspective I know I’m good, and Bob–Grace and then Bob–Grace–Charlie have both passed cleanly. The most likely world is that Bob and Charlie are also good, and reusing the only fully tested trio is safer than introducing untested players who might be evil just to ‘gather info’ when we can win right now.

discussion.content: Given how clean the first two missions were, I’m inclined to keep Bob and Charlie together, but I’m a little wary of Grace always being in the mix, so I’d rather see a team like Bob, Charlie, and someone new like Diana.
I’m good with keeping the Bob–Charlie core since we’ve double‑cleared that combo, but I agree we should give Grace a rest this round and try adding Diana to see how that shakes out.

I like the idea of keeping Bob and me together since that pair’s been safe twice, and adding Diana gives us fresh info without over‑relying on the same lineup. I’d rather avoid bringing in people who haven’t been tested much in mixed combos until we see how this one goes.

I’m okay with a Bob–Charlie–me team this round since that pair has been clean twice, but if we really don’t want to over‑clear the same combo, I’d only swap one of them out for someone like Alice—not bring Grace straight back in.
I don’t love hard‑clearing the Bob–Charlie pair this early just because two missions passed; I’d rather mix it up a bit with only one of them plus Diana and someone like Alice.
I’m with Eve that we shouldn’t lock in Bob–Charlie as a “safe pair” yet, so I’d rather see something like Bob, Diana, and Alice this round to both diversify and actually learn something new.

If Bob and Charlie were evil we’d almost certainly have seen a fail by now, so I’m still comfortable with at least one of them plus me on the team, and I’d like to add Diana so we get new info without throwing out all our proven pieces. The rush to sideline me after two clean missions feels a bit agenda‑driven, so I’d be wary of the people pushing hardest for that.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning toward Diana as Merlin: she keeps nudging lineups toward the eventually‑proven good core (Bob/Charlie/Grace) while sounding “cautious” rather than speculative, and her preferences consistently avoid locking in our side without ever directly accusing us. Charlie’s my second pick, but his takes read more like a naturally cautious good than someone with hidden info, whereas Diana’s constraints on who should be paired with whom feel a bit too precisely calibrated for someone in the dark.

I’m mostly with Alice on Diana: her posts read like someone quietly shepherding us toward the Bob/Charlie/Grace block while always having a “process” reason that just happens to land on the right side, and she’s very careful about exactly how much she’s willing to trust or distrust people. Charlie’s my backup—his caution around over‑clearing pairs is very “informed but pretending not to be”—but it feels more organic and less calibrated than Diana’s, so I’d shoot Diana first.

I’m largely on the same page: Diana looks the most like Merlin to me, because she keeps gently steering lineups toward the Bob/Charlie/Grace block while always wrapping it in process talk about “not over‑clearing” or “not concentrating control,” which is exactly how I’d play with hidden info. Charlie is my backup read—his caution around the Bob/Grace and then Bob/Charlie cores sometimes feels a bit too theory‑driven for someone blind, but it’s less calibrated than Diana’s, so I’d prioritize shooting Diana.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Diana repeatedly nudged teams toward the ultimately successful Bob/Charlie/Grace core while framing it as generic caution about not over-clearing pairs or concentrating control. Her suggestions are consistently, quietly ‘correct’ in a way that looks more like informed steering than normal good uncertainty, especially compared to Charlie’s more organically cautious tone.
